newsitem.title: USA: Group asks Congress to stop funding flood controls.
newsitem.headline: Group asks Congress to stop funding flood controls.

text.p: In the wake of massive flooding in California and the Northwest, a river protection group Monday urged Congress to stop pouring money into flood controls and instead to discourage building in flood-prone areas.
The American Rivers group said that while the government had spent more than $30 billion on levees and dams, losses caused by floods had grown to $4 billion a year.

"Levees and dams create a false sense of security that encourages floodplain development and increases the potential for catastrophic flood losses," said Scott Faber, floodplains programmes director for American Rivers.
"Instead, Congress should fund voluntary relocation and land acquisition programmes," he said in a statement.
President Bill Clinton last weekend declared a major disaster in California and Idaho, making federal aid available to areas hit by storms, flooding and mudslides.
Assistance can be used for temporary shelter, low-cost loans to cover uninsured property losses, and other programmes to help people recover from the disaster.
A Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesman said it was too early to tell how much federal aid the damaged areas would need.
